result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (3rd) and Operating w/PAC >= .02 Under IID Order (3rd). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (3rd) and the other charge, Operating w/PAC >= .02 Under IID Order (3rd) was dismissed by the court.

  • Charles Littlebear was found guilty of OWI (3rd), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Per Statute 343.301(g) your operating privileges for operation of Class D vehicles will require that vehicles owned and/or driven by you be equipped with an ignition interlock device.  Must install a mandatory Ignition Interlock Device when defendant obtains an occupational license or regular license.  There is a $50 ignition interlock surcharge imposed.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Any out of pocket costs for the alcohol assessment and driver's safety plan shall be subtracted from the fine and costs in this action, pursuant to sec. 346.65(2e) Wis. Stats.
Maintain employment, at the discretion of his agent.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located, except for purposes of employment only.

Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly licensed.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.

If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

timeConds.notes: All but the first 14 days stayed, pending successful completion of probation that includes alcohol and other drug treatment.  May serve in Columbia County.  EMP allowed, according to jail rules.  Sentence to start on or before May 18, 2016 at 6:00 pm.

supervisions.notes: A civil judgment has been entered against you for the unpaid court ordered financial obligations.
A civil judgment has been entered against you for the unpaid court ordered financial obligations.
Sentenced to 7 months jail with credit for 102 days served.  May serve balance of jail term in Columbia County Jail if arrangements can be made.

defendant.name: Littlebear, Charles
defendant.address: 710 2nd Avenue, c/o Eau Claire County Jail, Eau Claire, WI 54703

records.addlTxt: Notice of Intent returned.  "Inmate Not Here"

Defendant appears in person in custody with counsel SPD Amanda Roush.  Assistant District Attorney, Emily Hynek appeared on behalf of the State.  There are no victims in this matter.  Parties have reviewed the revocation summary.  Defense counsel notes one correction on page 1, 1st paragraph - he wasn't driving when he tested positive on his Soberlink, he was a passenger. 

State requests a 6 - 9 months jail sentence as recommended by the DOC.  Defense counsel makes statement to the Court and is requesting a lesser jail term.  Defendant exercises his right to allocution.  

Court orders a sentence of a 7 month jail term, civil judgment entered for court obligations left unpaid.  Grants credit of 102 days sentence credit.  May serve balance of jail term in Columbia County Jail if arrangements can be made.  SPD Amanda Roush states she will file the appeal rights later.
Amanda Roush
PD office called ask to convert to efiling
Sentencing hearing on revocation on June 14, 2018 at 02:00 pm.
sent to Judge Becker 5/25.  JMM

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.
Order for intox driver assessment and safety plan

records.addlTxt: Associated with Charge #1

ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody with Attorney Fredrickson.  Defendant plead guilty to Count 1, OWI 3rd.  Count 2 dismissed by operation of law.  Remaining counts dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes remaining counts.  Civil citations dismissed.    Court recited the charge and possible penalties on the count he plead to.  Defendant understood.  Priors confirmed by the court.   Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of OWI 3rd contrary to 346.63(1)(a) Wis. Stats.  State recommended 2 years probation.  $900.00 fine, plus costs.  95 days jail, stay all but first 14 days.  AODA.  DL Rev and IID,  27 months.  Attorney Fredrickson requests 1 year probation with the same conditions as requested by the State.  Court ordered:  sentence withheld, up to 2  years probation.  May apply for early discharge after 1 year.  $900.00 fine, plus costs. $2,122.00  95 days jail.  All but the first 14 days stayed on the condition he successfully complies with probation conditions.  May serve on EMP.  Start on or before May 18, 2016 at 6:00 pm.    May serve in Columbia County.  27 month DL revocation and IID.  Cost of AA/DSP may be subtracted from fine & costs.  Alcohol assmt and DSP.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  Maintain employment, at the discretion of his agent.     Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located, except for employment purposes only.    Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly licensed.  Submit DNA sample.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  Defendant shall not operate a motor vehicle on the highways until properly reinstated in the State of Wisconsin.
